title: unwanted 'Failed to open `.pgpass` file' warning with most basic use
body:
### Bug Description

``PgConnection::connect()`` executed with no password gives 'Failed to open `.pgpass` file', while this is a completely normal use case, so it should cause no warnings.

This seems some recent regression, as my code was not showing the warnings before switching to ``sqlx 0.8``.

Connecting to a local database with no password is perfectly normal and can be perfectly safe (PostgreSQL 'ident' authentication uses local system user account security).

This is similar to #3466, but covers even more basic use case, when no ``PgConnectOptions`` are used.

### Minimal Reproduction

```rust
#[tokio::main]
async fn main() {
    env_logger::builder()
        .filter(None, log::LevelFilter::Info)
        .init();
    use sqlx::Connection;
    sqlx::postgres::PgConnection::connect("postgres:///test")
        .await
        .unwrap();
    println!("connected!")
}
```

The code output:
```text
$ target/debug/sqlxtest
[2024-09-30T08:36:30Z WARN  sqlx_postgres::options::pgpass] Failed to open `.pgpass` file: Os { code: 2, kind: NotFound, message: "No such file or directory" } path=/home/jajcus/.pgpass
connected!
```

``psql`` does not complain in this case:
```text
$ psql test
psql (16.4 (Ubuntu 16.4-0ubuntu0.24.04.2))
Type "help" for help.

test=# \q
```

### Info
* SQLx version: 0.8.2
* SQLx features enabled: "runtime-tokio", "tls-native-tls", "postgres"
* Database server and version: PostgreSQL 16.4
* Operating system: Ubuntu 24.04.1 LTS Linux
* `rustc --version`: rustc 1.80.0 (051478957 2024-07-21)
